Nunc post Filii aeternitatem.
Lombard, Sent., I, d. 10, c. 1
This is the tenth distinction which is continued to the preceding thus because after the Master determined about the generation of the Son, now
he begins to treat about the procession of the Holy Spirit. And he divides this in tow parts because in the first place he determines about its mode of procession, in the second place about its productive principle. The second begins in the beginning of the distinction 11,
hic dicendum est
Lombardus, I, d. 11, c. 1
.

The first is divided in two because in the first place he shows how the Holy spirit proceeds or is produced, in the second place why it is expressed only by a common name. The second begins at
hic notandum est Lombardus, I, d. 10, c. 3 . The first is divided into two because he first shows the mode by which he proceeds or emanates, secondly he confirms what he says with authorities. The second begins at
nunc vero quod incepimus Lombardus, I, d. 10, c. XXX . And this is the division of this distinction.

Distinction 11 follows in which after the Master explained in the preceding the procession of the Holy Spirit, here regarding this he explains the double operation, which indeed is why distinction 11 is divided into two parts. For in the first place the Master shows the agreement of the Latins, in the second place he shows the disagreement of the Greeks. The second part begins at
Graeci tamen Lombardus, I, d. 11, c. 1 . The first part is divided into two because in the first place the Master introduces his intention. In the second place he ads his proof of what he said at
quod autem de utroque Lombardus, I, d. 11, c. 1, n. 2 . The second principal part is divided into two because he explains the agreement of the Greeks with the Latins, in the second place the disagreement at
nos non
autem verba determinamus
Lombardus, I, d. 11, c. 1, n. 9
. And this is the division of these two distinctions.

div.head: Question
div.p: Whether the Father and the Son in the same indistinct mode of acting produce the Holy Spirit in a supposite distinct from them.

That not because then it follows in the first place that it is only repugnant that the Holy Spirit is not produced by the Son just as it is not distinguished from it. The consequent is false because if, through the impossible, the Son were not to produce the Holy Spirit, this distinction between them would still exist, therefore. The first consequence is proved because, if in the same mode, the Father and Son spirate, then therefore the Father spirates in such a way that, if he were not to spirate the Holy Spirit, it would not be said to be from him. It follows that, if the Son also does not spirate, then it would also be distinguished.

In the second place, that the Son does not spirate the Holy Spirit is proved by the authority of
Damascene, in book one, chapters 10 and 11, saying
Spiritum Sanctum ex Patre dicimus et Patris Spiritum Sanctum nominamus ex Filio vero non dicimus sed Spiritum Filii nominamus Damescenus, De fide orthodoxa I, c. 8 . Therefore, if it is not from the Son, it does not seem to precede from him.

In the third place, if this is true, it would follow that it would naturally proceed from them. The consequent is false because it proceeds in the mode of love and of liberty or of the will. But the consequence is proved because internally there is a single mode of proceeding in the divine that cannot be made into a plurality as was said above. But the Son proceeds from the Father in a natural mode or naturally, therefore, if the Holy Spirit proceeds from something, this will be naturally and not freely.

In opposition is the position of the
master in distinction 11
Lombardus, I, d. 11, XXX , and
Extra, De summa Trinitatem and fide catholica, libro 6
Liber extra VI, 1, 1, 1 (CIC, II, 937).
.

First conclusion: though the Holy Spirit does not proceed from the Father prior or more greatly than from the Son, nevertheless that the Spirit is or proceeds from something is only able to be shown by means of faith. The first part is proved because for each sign the Holy Spirit is spirated from the Son, but for every sign for which it is spirated it is from the Father, therefore for any sign spirated by the Father for the same sign it is spirated by thed Son. The major premise is clear because, if the opposite were given, it follows that in some sign the Holy Spirit would from one only and not from two, contradicting the faith. The second, namely, the minor, is proved because for each for which there is active spiration, there is also passive spiration, therefore. The antecedent is proved because otherwise it would follow that the Father some sign would spirate the Holy Spirit for which sign the Holy Spirit would not be spirated, which is a contradiction. The second part of the conclusion is proved because it would follow that the Trinity of the divine persons would be able to be shown by evident reason, which is false as has been proven. Again, every argument short of faith proving that the Holy Spirit proceeds would prove that the Holy Spirit produces another Holy Spirit, just as was said about the generation of the Son. But that it is able to be shown by means of fatih is clear from
Extra, de summa trinitate and fide catholica, in book 6, the chapter on faith Liber Extra, Liber 6, Titulus Primus, De Summa Trinitate et Fide Catholica, c. 1 (Friedberg 1879 v. 11, col. 937) Concile de Lyon II (oecum. XIV), 7 mai - 17 juillet 1274 (sous le Bienheureux Grégoire X); Session II, 18 mai 1274: Constitution "de summa Trinitate et fide catholica", (Enchiridion Symbolorum, Denzinger. 850 460)
. Again through
Augustine IV De Trinitate, capitulo 53 de parvis Augustinus, De Trinitate, IV, c. 53, xxx , where he deduces this from many authorities of Sacred Scripture.

The first corollary: just as the Father does not speak
the Word earlier than he spirates the Holy Spirit, so the generation of the Divine Word is not really prior to the spiration of the Holy Spirit. The first is clear because the Son is not prior to the Holy Spirit, therefore. The antecedent is proved because, just as it is proved that the Father is not prior to the Son, so it is proved that the Son is not prior to the Holy Spirit. The second part is proved because in the divine there is no real priority in quo as it has been proved. Likewise if generation preceded spiration, it would follow that what is generated would precede what is spirated, which has been disproved.

The second corollary: that in God the Son produces the Holy Spirit causally because it exists as its express image and perfect likeness. This is clear because by the same reason it would be proved that the Holy Spirit produces the Son, therefore.

Third corollary: not precisely from the fact that since the Son is God the Son spirates or produces the Holy Spirit. This is clear because it would be proved that the Holy Spirit would produces its very self or another that is the Son. And the consequence is clear because it is no less God that the Father or the Son is.

Second conclusion: though nothing other than active spiration is distinctive of the Holy Spirit from the Son nevertheless the following is not a formal consequence the Holy Spirit is not produced by the Son, therefore the Son is not distinguished from the Holy Spirit. The first part is proved because nothing is in the Son that is not active spiration, therefore. In the second place, because if it were distinguished through something else, it follows that the Son would not be most simple. The consequence is clear because there are many incomplex entities in it. The second part is proved because the Son is not precisely distinguished from the Holy Spirit because he precisely spirate it, therefore the consequnence is not formal. The consequence is clear because in this consequence it is argued from causes of truth to one, but such a consequence is not valid. But the principal antecedent is argued because the Son is distinguished sufficiently form the Holy Spirit through the fact that he proceeds from the Father by being born and the Holy Spirit does not, but only by proceeding. This argument is also confirmed by the saying of Augustine V De Trinitate, chapter 14 therefore the Holy Spirit is not the Son though both come from the father because he
comes not in the mode of being born but of being given
Augustinus, De Trinitate V, c. 14, n. 15 (PL 42:XX) . Item De Fide Catholica, chapter 2,
one is born, the other proceeds, therefore one is the Son, the other is the Holy Spirit De Fide Catholica, XXX .

The first corollary: The relative opposition alone is not distinctive of the divine persons. This is clear because, if there were no opposition of this type between the Son and the Holy Spirit, they would still be distinguished through the conclusion. This is confirmed because the divine persons are distinguished in themselves and not only through relations. This corollary is in opposition to
Thomas of Argentina, in book 1, distinction 11, question 2, article 2
Thomas de Argentina, I, c. 11, q. 2, a. 2 .

The second corollary: if, through the impossible, the Son were not to produce the Holy Spirit, it would still be the case that no divine person would proceed through generation and spiration. This is contrary to
Giles, in Quodlibet 1, question 6 Aegidius Romanos, Quodlibet I, q. 6. . It is likewise opposed to
Ockham Ockham, XXX
and
Aureolus
Aureolus, XXX . This is proved because, in this case, it the produced persons would still be sufficiently distinguished from one another, as it is said in the second part of the conclusion
second part of the conclusion See above .

Third corollary: the following consequence is neither evident nor formal, the Holy Spirit does not proceed from the Son, therefore the Holy Spirit is not and does not exist, against
Gregory, in book 1, distinction 11, article 2
Gregorius Ariminiensis, I, d. 11, a. 2 . The corollary is clear because, if the consequence were formal, it would follow that, if the Spirit were not produced from the Word, it would not be distinguished from it, which is disproved in the conclusion. This is confirmed because the Holy Spirit is sufficiently distinguished from the Word through something incomplex besides spiration, therefore, apart from spiration, whether this is impossible or possible, the Holy Spirit would still be distinguished from the Word. The antecedent is his in
article one of the same question Vide supra
and the consequence is clear through what has been said.

Third conclusion: though the Father communicates active spiration to the Son nevertheless the Holy Spirit is produced by each in the same natural and free mode. The first part is clear in
distinction 12 of book 1 Lombard, I, d. 12, XXX
in which it is said that the Father gives to the Son that he spirates the Holy Spirit, therefore. But that they produce the Holy Spirit in a natural mode is clear from the authority of
Hilary V De trinitate Hilarius, De Trinitate, V, XXX , and this is alleged by the Master in his text where he says
from the virtue of nature in nature the Holy Spirit
subsists under the same procession
Lombardus, I, Distinctio 18, C. 3
but that it proceeds freely is clear because it is voluntarily, as
Augustine says in 15 De Trinitate capitulo 17
Augustinus, De Trinitate, XV, c. 17, XXX . See the source. This is also confirmed because it is not repugnant that the Son is generated naturally and freely, therefore nor is it repugnant that the Holy Spirit is spirated naturally and freely. The consequence is clear the similarity, but the antecedent is proved above.

The first corollary: the Spirit of immense goodness is not produced through the mode of the will, contrary to
Scouts, in book1, distinction 18, in question one, in article one
Scotus, I, d. 18, q. 1, a.1
and contrary to
Ockham, in the same distinction, in the first question
Ockham, I, d. 18, q. 1 . This is proved because either will is understood essentially or notionally. Not the first because it is certain that the will does not produce the Son nor the Holy Spirit. Not the second because then the Holy Spirit would produce itself. The consequence is clear through
Augustine 15 De Trinitate, chapter 3 de magnis and 16 de parvis
where he says
The will of God, if properly said, is some person in the Trinity, the name best fits the Holy Spirit, just as love. For what is love besides the will?
Augustinus, De Trinitate, 15, 20, 38 . Through this argument Augustine argues against Eunomius the heretic that the Son is not the son of the will or is from the will.

Second corollary: in the same beginning, with respect to the term of the same thing, liberty and necessity concur in active spiration in a unified way. This is proved because a single term is simple, namely the Holy Spirit, but this is produced from the Father and the Son freely and naturally and necessary through spiration. Nevertheless note that this is not the liberty of contradiction but of pleasure and of natural love, against Gregory in his opposition to Scotus.
The third corollary is part what is asked in the affirmative.

Against the first conclusion, it is argued in the first place thus from the authority of
Dionysius, in chapter 2 of the On the Divine Names
who says
one should not dare to speak about the Holy Spirit a and the divine mysteries beyond things which are divinely expressed to us from the holy texts
Dionysius, De diivnis nominibus, I (PG 3, 587) . But in the holy texts of the canons this truth does not seem to be expressed, therefore it should not be asserted.

In the second place, it follows that the identity between the Father and the Son is greater than between the Father and the Holy Spirit. The consequent is false. The consequence is clear because the identity of essence is beyond the identity of active spiration.

In the third place, for any absolutely simple actions there is one principle, therefore. But this is false which it is proved in the first place because, if there were one principle spirating the Holy Spirit, then there would be some fourth person in the divine, since the neither the Father nor the Son is this one principle.
In the second place, it follows that there are only two persons there. This is proved because there is only the spirative principle and and spirated principle or the terminus of spiration.
In the third place, it follows that the Father and Son are somehow one, and the Holy Spirit would it not be one in this way. The consequent is false, and the consequence is clear because the Father and the Son are one principle of the Holy Spirit, but the Holy Spirit is not thus one with them, therefore. The antecedent is clear because otherwise it would follow int he first place that the same indivisible terminus with a single relation would be referred to many. In the second place, that one and the same thing could be produced absolutely from many total causes was disproved above. In the third place, it follows that the effect depends on a cause, which when removed, nothing less would be produced. This is false, therefore.

In fourth place principally, either this truth follows necessarily and expressily from what has been said in Sacred Scriptures or not. If the first, then it is marvelous that the doctors of Greece , such as Damascene, Theophilus, Gregory of Nazianzus, and Cyril, have not seen this. If the second, it follows that we ought not to teach this, nor should the faithful be pressed to believe this, and nor should the opposite be labeled heretical.

In the fifth place, some principle of the Holy Spirit is not the Son, therefore no principle of the Holy Spirit is the Son. The antecedent is clear because the Father, who is not the Son, is the principle of the Holy Spirit. And the consequence is proved because in natural material the indefinite or singular implies something universal, just as in the proposed.

Against the second conclusion it is argued in the first place thus: from whatever something is constituted in existence,
it is distinguished from that for the same reason. But the Son is constituted in existence by personal filiation. Therefore, circumscribed by possible or impossible spiration, the Son will remain personally distinct from every other person, therefore not only is he distinguished from the Holy Spirit through spiration, as it says in the first part of the conclusion. This is the argument of Scotus
Scoti, in distinction 11, question 2 Scotus, I, d. 11, q. 2 .

In the second place, between the divine persons there is not able to be a distinction unless through some opposition, which is not able to be unless it is relative opposition. But such opposition is not able to be unless through some origin. Therefore, if there is no origin of the Holy Spirit from the Word, neither is there any relation, therefore there is no distinction. See
the Holy Doctor in the Summa, first part, question 36, article 2
Aquinas, Summa, I, q. 36, a. 2 .

Against the second corollary: active generation and active spiration in the Father mean the same thing, therefore passive generation would deal with passive spiration unless dealt with active generation. But if the Holy Spirit did not proceed from the Son, then passive generation would not deal with active spiration, therefore the same thing would be a generated and spirated person. See
Thomas, where he is cited above Aquinas, XXX .

Against the third corollary: the Holy Spirit would not be if it did not proceed from the Son. This consequence is formal the Holy Spirit does not proceed from the Son, therefore it is not distinguished from him. The consequence is sound because what is distinguished from nothing does not exist. The antecedent is proved in three ways. First because, if the Holy Spirit did not proceed from the Son, then there would not be a gift of the the Father and the Son, therefore nor would there be the Holy Spirit. In the second place, because the Son through itself is the principle of the Holy Spirit, therefore if he did not spirate it, then the Holy Spirit would not be. In the third place, if some creature did not proceed from the from the Son, then it would not be produced by the Son or by the Father, therefore it will thus be from the Holy Spirit. And as a consequence., if the Son did not produce the Holy Spirit, then it would not exist. This is the argument of
our Doctor Gregory, in distinction 11 of the first book, article 2 Gregorius Ariminiensis, I, d. 11, a. 2 .

Against the third conclusion: the Father sufficiently produces the Holy Spirit, therefore it is superflous for the Son to produce. The consequence is valid because, just as it would be in vain that something happens through many etc, a fortiori many would be in vain for what is in fact sufficiently done through one alone. But God and nature never do anything in vain, therefore. The antecedent is proved because something is not more perfectly produced by two things than it is by one alone.

In the second place, in someway the Father produces the Holy Spirit in a way that the Son does not produce it, therefore not in the same mode. The antecedent is proved because the Father does not have his own producing from another, but the Son has his from the Father, therefore.

In the third place, diverse acts belong to divers supposits, but the Father and the Son are divers supposites, therefore, if they spirate, they are diverse spirations and diverse acts. The consequent is false. The consequence is clear because, though two angels love themelves, nevertheless it does not follow that there is one love between the two of them, therefore so it is in the divine.

Against the first corollary: the will is the internal productive principle, and it is not this unless it is of love, therefore the Spirit is produced out of immense goodness. See
Scotus, in distinction 10
Scotus, I, d. 10 .

Against the second corollary: it would follow, if this were the case, that there is no difference between the free and the necessary, contra
the Philosopher IX Metaphysicae
Aristoteles, Metaphysicae, IX . And the consequent is proved by
Gregory, in distinction 10, article 2, consluion 2 Gregorius Ariminiensis, I, d. 10, a. 2, c. 2 .

Against the third corollary: the productive principle of the Holy Spirit is the will, therefore it is produced freely and not naturally or necessarily. The consequence is clear because, just as the intellect does not have a mode of acting freely, so the will does not have a natural mode. The antecedent is clear because the Holy Spirit is love, therefore it is produced from the will. This is the argument of
Alphonsus, in distinction 11 of book 1, article 2, conclusion 3 Alphonsus Vargas, Sent. I, d. 11, a. 2, concl. 3

In the second place, the Holy Spirit is not produced by being born in someway, therefore it is not produced naturally. The antecedent is from
Augustine, in book [?] De Trinitate, chapter 12 Augustinus, De Trinitate, XXX, c. 12, xxx . The consequence is proved because whatever is produced naturally in the same nature with what is producing is produced as if born, therefore, from the opposite, what is not produced as if born, is not produced naturally, therefore the consequence was valid.

div.head: Responses
div.p:
To the first, which is the saying of Dionysius, it is said that the authority and similar things ought to be understood through another or beyond, and thus that is contrary or in an adverse way, as is clear since Dionysius himself teaches many things which are not expressly in the canon, and in this way many other
authorities are able to be explained.
To the second, the consequence is denied, and to the proof it is said that the identity of spiration does not add some further essential thing.

To the third, in the first place the consequent would be possible to concede, just as
Thomas says, in the first part, question 36, article 4 Aquinas, Summa Theologica, I, q. 36, a. 4 . But this does not seem consistent with what he says in his Scriptum, book 1, where he says
we are not able to say that the Father and the Son is a spirating or a spirator, but we ought to say that they are two spirating things or spirators because they are two supposits Aquinas, Scriptum, I, d. 12, q. 1 , while in his Summa as noted above he says that
they ought not to be called two spirators on account of one spiration Aquinas I, q. 36 a. 4 ad 7 .

In the second place, Our Gregory would says that this proposition, the Father and the Son are one principle of the Holy Spirit, is valid only in the following way, The Father and the Son in one and the same mode, as if one principle, spirate the Holy Spirit. And thus he would not concede that the Father and the Son are one productive or spirative principle of the Holy Spirit because there are two things which spirates. See the arguments he gives there.

In the third place, Hugolino would say, as if following Gregory, there is not one principle of spirating the Holy Spirit, when understanding the word one strictly for a simple single number because either it would this essence or two persons or only or the aggregate from the essence and relation or the common relation, but none of these ought to be said, therefore. In the second place he says the same thing because when
the Decretals say in the Liber extra, on the highest trinity, in book 6 ,
fideliter fatemur capitulo quod Spiritus Sanctus aeternaliter ex Patre et Filio tamquam non ex duobus principis sed tamquam ex uno principio non duabus spirationibus sed una spiratione procedit
Liber Extra, Liber 6, Titulus Primus, De Summa Trinitate et Fide Catholica, c. 1 (Friedberg 1879 v. 11, col. 937) Concile de Lyon II (oecum. XIV), 7 mai - 17 juillet 1274 (sous le Bienheureux Grégoire X); Session II, 18 mai 1274: Constitution "de summa Trinitate et fide catholica", (Enchiridion Symbolorum, Denzinger. 850 460)
, it ought not to be understood that the Decretals did not intend to affirm the one principle or the unity of the principle, but rather the unity or the uniformity of the mode of beginning, Therefore it does not say as if from two principles, Likewise, it wished to assert the numerical unity of the spiration or procession of the Holy Spirit. From the things which have been said, it is clear that, though according to him, this is not true The Father and the Son are one principle of the Holy Spirit, nevertheless this common conclusion is put forward by the doctors.

In the fourth place, it would be able to be said that, though it is conceded that the Father and the Son are one principle of the Holy Spirit, nevertheless it should not be conceded that they are the same principle of the Holy Spirit, lest the identity of the person should be understood. Again, it should not be conceded that the Father is another principle of the Holy Spirit besides the Son, lest there is noted a plurality of spiration.

In the fifth place, it should be noted that it should not be conceded that the Father and the Son are some principle of the Holy Spirit on account of the word something which is a principle denoting a intrinsic relation, just as it is not admitted that the Father and the Son are some God.

In the sixth place, it should be known that in the Sexto, notandum quod habetur in
cardinal gloss of the Liber Extra, De summa trinitate Cardinalis glossa in libro extra, xxx , mentioned above, on the phrase single spiration, where the gloss objects saying, many things are many supposits, therefore there are many actions because actions belong to supposites. The glosa responds saying where there are many supposites and many reasons of acting, there are many actions, where there are many supposites and a single reason of acting, it is not necessary for there to be many actions, just as it is stated in what was proposed because, though the Father and the Son spirate, nevertheless because there is one reason, therefore there is one spiration.

From what has been said it would be able to be inferred otherwise to the form by denying that one part of the action is the principle. And to the proof, because if not, etc., this consequent is conceded just as the by the same whiteness Socrates is similar to white Plato and dissimilar to black John.

To the second, what is inferred is conceded, just as it was explained in the fifth distinction when speaking about the totality of the produced term because the entire Holy Spirit is produced by the Son, nevertheless it is not the cause of it.
To the third, the consequent is also conceded.

To the fourth principal argument, it is said that this truth follows from the sayings of Sacred Scripture, as
Augustine says above XXX
and
the Master in this distinction Lombardus, I, d. 10[?] , adding to this many authorities of the New Testament which are clear in the text. And when it is said
the doctor somehow etc. Vide supra , it is said that perhaps the stubbornness of them was and is the cause of their blindness and ignorance.
To the fifth, the consequence would be able to be denied, and further it would be able to be said that this logical rule is not general but precise, where predication is absolute and essential.

In the second place, it is said that the form is not valid because it would be said absolutely that something is
the Father and not the Son, therefore the essence, which is the Father, is not the Son, which is false.

To the first against the second conclusion, the major is conceded, but the minor is denied, both because no divine person is constituted in personal being, and also because the Son is constituted in his personal being through nothing that is not formally the Son himself.

To the second, int he first place it is able to be said that the argument is founded a false assumption, because it is imagined that the divine persons are not distinguished among themselves but only through relations, which is denied.
In the second place, have conceded this, they are nevertheless not only distinguished through opposite relations but also through disparate relations.

To the argument against the second corollary, the consequence is denied because this is not the argument for why paternity and active spiration do not constitute two persons because they are not opposite relations, but rather it is because active spiration is communicable to the Son, therefore it is not constitutive of a supposite. And this is clear because, if this argument was actually true, then the Son and the Holy Spirit would not be two persons because the Son and the Holy Spirit are not constituted by diverse opposite relations because in the Son there is not opposition to passive spiration. This is the response of
Alphonsus, distinction 11 of the first book, in article two Alphonsus Vargas, I, d. 11, a. 2 . Besides this, I say that the argument is founded upon something false because it is imagined that the constitution and distinction of persons is through relations and that the persons are not distinguished through themselves, which should not be said.

To the argument against the third corollary, the antecedent is denied. And to the proof, because then they would not be, the consequence would be able to be denied. In the first place and to the authorities of the Apostle and Augustine it is said that they speak as it is now, but not as it would be in that case. In the second place, it would be able to be called the gift of the Son, and then it would, but not be, the gift of the Son. In the third place, it would be possible that the consequence is denied because, though it would not be a gift of the Son such that it would be from the Son, nevertheless it would be a gift of the Son because it would be give by the Son, just as the Greeks in fact say.
To the second, the consequence is denied his motive.
To the third of the same, the consequence is also denied because there is no similarity between inner notional acts and external essential acts.

To the first against the third conclusion, it is said by some that the consequence is not valid on account of the single principle of spirating or on account of the single power of producing which is the divine essence. However, because to this it follows that the divine essence is the principle by which is the source of production, which I do not say, therefore I respond otherwise by denying the consequence because otherwise it would follow similarly that the Father sufficiently is God, therefore the Son or the Holy Spirit is superfluously God. Again, only the Father sufficiently produces creatures, therefore three divine persons produce these superfluously.
To the second, in the first place it would be possible to deny the antecedent absolutely.

In the second place Master John Klenkok would respond by denying the consequence, while conceding the antecedent because it would produce by the same thing, namely the Father himself would produced the Holy Spirit in a different way than he would produce the Son and the Father would produce the Holy Spirit in one way and the Son would produce the Holy Spirit in another way. And if it is objected through the
Decretals Liber Extra, I, c. 1
which says that they produce equally and together, it would be able to be said that this equality to origination ought to be referred to as active because bot the Father and the Son are actively originating or spirating the Holy Spirit.

In the third place, it would be able to be said that the word otherwise is able to be taken adverbially, and thus the antecedent is conceded and the consequence is denied, or nominally, and thus the antecedent is denied and the consequence is conceded.

In the fourth place, it is able to be said that the word otherwise is able to indicate the Father himself or the production itself or the Holy Spirit. If the it is taken in the second or third way, then the antecedent is denied, if in the second way, the consequence is denied.

To the third, the universally supposed antecedent is denied because otherwise creation would be a three-fold act, since it is an act of three supposites. And to the proof about the two angels, it is said that the cases are not similar on account of the essential identity of the divine supposites.
To another argument against the first corollary, I say in the first place that the will is not formal productive principle, at least internally.

In the second place, it is able to be said that, since
no thing begets or produces itself, and between the will and the Holy Spirit there is no distinction, therefore the argument does not work.

To another argument against the second corollary, the consequent is conceded about the liberty of immutability because this is not repugnant to the highest necessity, and it is regarding this that the corollary speaks.

To another, the antecedent is denied. And the to the proof, the consequence is denied when taking will essentially, just as I have understood it. Nevertheless it indeed follows that something which is the will is the principle of the Holy Spirit because the Father and also the Son. In the second place, it is said that it does not follow, that love is an act of the will, therefore it is not natural because nature or naturally is taken in many ways, just as
Scotus shows in distinction 10 of the first book Scotus, I, d. 10, xxx , and similarly
Bonsemblantes Bonsemblantes, xxxx .

To another, the consequence is denied. And to the proof because whatever is produced, etc., this is denied, for it does not seem a greater inconvenience that the Holy Spirit produces naturally than that the Son exists voluntarily, and nevertheless the Master, in distinction 6 of book 1, in the last chapter says
Dicamus ergo, quod Pater sicut sapiens, ita volens genuit Filium
Lombardus, I, d. 6, c. 1, n. 7 , so similarly it seems possible to say about the Holy Spirit
To the first and the third reasons of the opposition, the solution is clear from what has been said.

To the second, Our Doctor Giles responds in the first place that opinion of Damascenus should not stand because he was Greek. Alternatively
Thomas of Strasbourg
Aegidius Romanus, Sent. I, d. 11, princ. 1, q. 1 (Venice 1521, 64rb-va).
says, in order to save what Damascene says, that the Greeks believed well and would have believed this article, except that they were not called to the council where this was ordered for belief, therefore they did not wish to believe. In the second place he says that these words from or out of signify among the Greeks something which begins what has begun, which is not suitable to the Son, which is why they do not deny that the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Son, but they deny that it proceeds chiefly from him, and this seems to be consonant with the truth.

Nunc post Filii aeternitatem. Lombard, I, d. 10, c. 1, n. 1
This distinction contains four conclusions. The first is that the Holy Spirit is the love or charity or delight of the Father and the Son by which the Father and the Son love each other and us.

Second conclusion: that love sometimes refers to a substance which is common to three persons total in each individual, sometimes specially to the person of the Holy Spirit, just as the divine wisdom is sometimes take for the divine substance, and sometimes take for the Son.

Third conclusion: just as the Holy Spirit in the Trinity means specifically the charity which is the union of the Father and the Son, so also the name holds rightly that it commonly somehow applies to the Father and the Son.

hic dicendum est Lombardus, I, d. 11, c. 1, n. 1
etc. This distinction 11 contains four conclusions. The first is that the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father and the Son according to the Latin doctors and according to the truth which is proved through the testimony of many doctors and Holy Scripture.

Second conclusion: though the Greeks and confess and conceded that the Holy Spirit is the spirit of the Son, nevertheless they say that the Holy Spirit only proceeds from the Father and not from the Son.

Third conclusion: when it is said
anyone who teaches or preaches something other is anathema Lombardus, I, d. 11, c. 1, n. 8 , this should be understood as, anyone who preached in a mode opposite or contrary is anathema.

The fourth conclusion: The Greeks conceding that the Holy Spirit is the spirit of the Son hold the same opinion with us in faith because to say that it is the spirit of the Father or the Son is nothing other than to say that is or proceeds from the Father and the Son.

From this it seems to follow that the Greeks only differ from us in word because the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Son just as from the Father. This is clear through many Greek doctors, whence the Subtle Doctor says
among the Latin and G Greeks there is no real or vocal discord. Scotus, XXX .
